from plotly.offline import iplot
import plotly.graph_objs as go

daily_new_cases = go.Scatter(x=df1.index,y=df1['daily_new_cases'],yaxis='y1',name='Daily confirmed cases')
daily_vaccinations = go.Scatter(x=df2.index,y=df2['daily_vaccinations'],yaxis='y2',name='Daily vaccinations')

#insert 'Layout' object to combine all of this
layout_obj = go.Layout(title='COVID vs. Vaccines',xaxis=dict(title='Date'),yaxis=dict(title='Daily cases'),yaxis2=dict(title='Vaccinations',side='right',overlaying='y'))
fig = go.Figure(data=[daily_new_cases,daily_vaccinations],layout=layout_obj)
iplot(fig)
fig.write_html('outcome.html')

# Successful in reducing the COVID-19 cases in Germany

https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-germany-vaccination-s-idUSL5N2NE47D

According to this article published in May 27, after a sluggish start to its vaccination rollout, Germany has increased the pace of inoculations and imposed nationwide lockdown measures which are now being lifted.
If we see the graph, we can also find that the inoculations has been increasing rapidly. And at the same time, the number of people who was infected with COVID-19 has decreased.

Germany seems to plan to make enough COVID-19 vaccine doses available to offer a first shot to all children by the end of August.
They prioritize the adolescents (aged 12 to 18), because they lack in data on long-term effects. 

What I found interesting is that, there is a big difference of the strategies between Germany and Japan.
Germany focuses on protecting children, while Japan's focus is the elderly people.

# Children prioritization in Germany

https://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/9/413058/World/International/Germany-to-vaccinate-children-over--from-June-.aspx

According to this article published in May 27, 
Chancellor Angela Merkel stressed that vaccination would have NO bearing on whether children can attend school or go on holiday, roughly in time for the new school year.
That's why Germany prioritize the children and protect the quality of education.
